oai_dc:dc.dc:title: South Guthrie ASA Paper: brochure
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: American Studies Association Kentucky-Tennessee Chapter
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Brochure for the 48th annual meeting of the Kentucky-Tennessee Chapter of American Studies Association, held at the Shaker Village of Pleasant Hill, in Harrodsburg, KY. Part of the program includes a research paper on South Guthrie, TN. Established in 1868, Guthrie is a town of the New South. When a railroad junction was completed there in 1870, the town became more than a place name and started to grow. Race sharply defined the town's physical environment, with Guthrie, KY as a white settlement, and South Guthrie, TN inhabited by African Americans. The listed research paper, presented to the American Studies Association Kentucky-Tennessee Chapter, discusses the Vinegar Hill Cemetery, Guildfield Baptist Church, and the Warfield Rosenwald School.

Kentucky-Tennessee ASA seks to support and foster the study of the history, society, and culture of the region; to bring those interested in the region together to explore its dynamcs; and to encourage interdisciplinary research, publication and teaching.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American neighborhoods
